values.description:
I've noticed that computing the overall mean and variance from the label-wise means and variances computed by segtools-signal-distribution often produces slightly different results depending on the input annotation, even though the overall mean and variance are for the same set of positions.  This appears to be due to numeric issues in calculating the label-wise means and variances.  I'm guessing this instability stems from the fact that we're repeatedly adding small numbers (values from a particular position) to large numbers (the running sum and sum of squares).  

This numeric instability is probably not a problem in most situations, but it's causing a problem for me when I'm comparing the residual variance of different annotations.  I got rid of most of the problem simply by converting the data from genomedata to double precision before summing, but it's not ideal.

Let me know if you think of any way of reducing the instability.  In the meantime, be careful not to overestimate the precision of the numbers from segtools-signal-distribution.
values.title: segtools-signal-distribution is numerically unstable

summary.raw:
I've noticed that computing the overall mean and variance from the label-wise means and variances computed by segtools-signal-distribution often produces slightly different results depending on the input annotation, even though the overall mean and variance are for the same set of positions.  This appears to be due to numeric issues in calculating the label-wise means and variances.  I'm guessing this instability stems from the fact that we're repeatedly adding small numbers (values from a particular position) to large numbers (the running sum and sum of squares).  

This numeric instability is probably not a problem in most situations, but it's causing a problem for me when I'm comparing the residual variance of different annotations.  I got rid of most of the problem simply by converting the data from genomedata to double precision before summing, but it's not ideal.

Let me know if you think of any way of reducing the instability.  In the meantime, be careful not to overestimate the precision of the numbers from segtools-signal-distribution.
summary.html:
I've noticed that computing the overall mean and variance from the label-wise means and variances computed by segtools-signal-distribution often produces slightly different results depending on the input annotation, even though the overall mean and variance are for the same set of positions. This appears to be due to numeric issues in calculating the label-wise means and variances. I'm guessing this instability stems from the fact that we're repeatedly adding small numbers (values from a particular position) to large numbers (the running sum and sum of squares).

This numeric instability is probably not a problem in most situations, but it's causing a problem for me when I'm comparing the residual variance of different annotations. I got rid of most of the problem simply by converting the data from genomedata to double precision before summing, but it's not ideal.

Let me know if you think of any way of reducing the instability. In the meantime, be careful not to overestimate the precision of the numbers from segtools-signal-distribution.

values.description:
* init

* Replace call of function 'set' with faster set literal {}

set literal can be at least 15 times faster than the 'set' function:

%timeit set(["+", "-"])
1000000 loops, best of 3: 282 ns per loop

%timeit {"-", "+"}
100000000 loops, best of 3: 17.2 ns per loop
values.title: Replace call to set() with faster set literal {}

summary.raw:
* init

* Replace call of function 'set' with faster set literal {}

set literal can be at least 15 times faster than the 'set' function:

%timeit set(["+", "-"])
1000000 loops, best of 3: 282 ns per loop

%timeit {"-", "+"}
100000000 loops, best of 3: 17.2 ns per loop
summary.html:
• init

  • Replace call of function 'set' with faster set literal {}

set literal can be at least 15 times faster than the 'set' function:

%timeit set(["+", "-"]) 1000000 loops, best of 3: 282 ns per loop

%timeit {"-", "+"} 100000000 loops, best of 3: 17.2 ns per loop

values.description:
Full list of R packages needed: "cluster", "plyr", "grDevices", "latticeExtra", "reshape2", "lattice", "grid", "Cairo", "RColorBrewer"

List of non-default R packages needed: "plyr", "latticeExtra", "reshape2", "Cairo", "RColorBrewer"

Note that it is possible to remove core R packages, so not sure which list would be preferred for installation.

values.description:
Change segtools-aggregation to output a mx1 column rather than a mxn grid. This way, all labels will be displayed (rather than only those on the left side).

For example:

Previously:

![feature_aggregation.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/LpoMnd/images/1863505866-feature_aggregation.png)

Now:

![feature_aggregation.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/LpoMnd/images/1946125056-feature_aggregation.png)

It is also possible to decrease the image width by changing line 461 of R/aggregation.R (and all other image width parameters) to:

```
#!R

461               width = image.size / 2,
```
resulting in:

![feature_aggregation.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/nRkGGL/images/1609603809-feature_aggregation.png)
values.title: Change segtools-aggregation to output a mx1 column rather than a mxn grid.

values.description:
This is a re-submission of the pull request #5 after revision

fix cast float to int numpy arrays described in the Issue #38

* fix cast float to int numpy arrays.

* use new built-in linspace dtype argument to return an array of int instead of casting manually.

* fix internal_bins not rounded

* Stop running if num_internal_bins is a negative value

* init

* add fix description to NEWS
values.title: fix internal_bins not rounded (cleaner PR #5)

summary.raw:
This is a re-submission of the pull request #5 after revision

fix cast float to int numpy arrays described in the Issue #38

* fix cast float to int numpy arrays.

* use new built-in linspace dtype argument to return an array of int instead of casting manually.

* fix internal_bins not rounded

* Stop running if num_internal_bins is a negative value

* init

* add fix description to NEWS
summary.html:
This is a re-submission of the pull request #5 after revision

fix cast float to int numpy arrays described in the Issue #38

  • fix cast float to int numpy arrays.

  • use new built-in linspace dtype argument to return an array of int instead of casting manually.

  • fix internal_bins not rounded

  • Stop running if num_internal_bins is a negative value

  • init

  • add fix description to NEWS

values.description:
Hi,
We found this error while testing segtools:

```
#!python

TypeError: Cannot cast ufunc add output from dtype('float64') to dtype('int64') with casting rule 'same_kind'
```

The error disappears with this patch
values.title: Fix numpy error

values.description:
segtools-feature-distance records the distance between a segment and an annotation in a variable named counts. The counts variable was erroneously re-initialized for each chromosomes so at the end of the run,  counts contains only the count for the last chromosome.

This fix initializes the counts variable at the beginning of the function, before looping over each chromosomes so all the counts are preserved.
values.title: Fix feature distance behavior

summary.raw:
segtools-feature-distance records the distance between a segment and an annotation in a variable named counts. The counts variable was erroneously re-initialized for each chromosomes so at the end of the run,  counts contains only the count for the last chromosome.

This fix initializes the counts variable at the beginning of the function, before looping over each chromosomes so all the counts are preserved.
summary.html:
segtools-feature-distance records the distance between a segment and an annotation in a variable named counts. The counts variable was erroneously re-initialized for each chromosomes so at the end of the run, counts contains only the count for the last chromosome.

This fix initializes the counts variable at the beginning of the function, before looping over each chromosomes so all the counts are preserved.

values.description:
* python-modernize run on wanted features and dependencies
* gmtk-parameters \+ length\_distribution compatibility with python 3 without html creation
* Fixed issues with pickles and strings: aggregation, preprocess and feature-distance tools available for python 3 too
* Added six as a dependency
* added this version to NEWS
* updated minimum version to 2.7.0
* Fixed issues

‌
values.title: Added compatibility with python 3 for the tools gmtk_parameters and length_distribution

summary.raw:
* python-modernize run on wanted features and dependencies
* gmtk-parameters \+ length\_distribution compatibility with python 3 without html creation
* Fixed issues with pickles and strings: aggregation, preprocess and feature-distance tools available for python 3 too
* Added six as a dependency
* added this version to NEWS
* updated minimum version to 2.7.0
* Fixed issues

‌
summary.html:
• python-modernize run on wanted features and dependencies
  • gmtk-parameters + length_distribution compatibility with python 3 without html creation
  • Fixed issues with pickles and strings: aggregation, preprocess and feature-distance tools available for python 3 too
  • Added six as a dependency
  • added this version to NEWS
  • updated minimum version to 2.7.0
  • Fixed issues

‌

values.description:
`genomedata` is only used in the `segtools-signal-distribution` command so I moved the import statement in the function called by the entry point.

Specifically it allows segtools modules to import elements from the `signal_distribution` module without requiring `genomedata` which is not a dependency.
values.title: move genomedata import to the entry point of signal_distribution

summary.raw:
`genomedata` is only used in the `segtools-signal-distribution` command so I moved the import statement in the function called by the entry point.

Specifically it allows segtools modules to import elements from the `signal_distribution` module without requiring `genomedata` which is not a dependency.
summary.html:
genomedata is only used in the segtools-signal-distribution command so I moved the import statement in the function called by the entry point.

Specifically it allows segtools modules to import elements from the signal_distribution module without requiring genomedata which is not a dependency.

values.description:
* updated README.rst
* Added compatibility table to the Usage part of the documentation
* Modernized documentation's .py
* Fixed issue with entry points and documentation:

    * Entry points need to be strings for them to be parsed with configparser
    * New py2\_entry\_points and py3\_entry\_points allow for tools to be compatible only for python 3
    

‌
values.title: Documentation update Python 3

summary.raw:
* updated README.rst
* Added compatibility table to the Usage part of the documentation
* Modernized documentation's .py
* Fixed issue with entry points and documentation:

    * Entry points need to be strings for them to be parsed with configparser
    * New py2\_entry\_points and py3\_entry\_points allow for tools to be compatible only for python 3
    

‌
summary.html:
• updated README.rst
  • Added compatibility table to the Usage part of the documentation
  • Modernized documentation's .py

  • Fixed issue with entry points and documentation:

    • Entry points need to be strings for them to be parsed with configparser
    • New py2_entry_points and py3_entry_points allow for tools to be compatible only for python 3

‌

values.description:
`segtools-length-distribution` generates two plots with different y axis labels referring to the same thing.

segment_sizes says "Segment label" whereas length_distribution only says "Label".

This PR changes the `R` code generating these figures such that the y axis labels are always "Label"
values.title: synchronize y-axis label names in segtools-length-distribution

summary.raw:
`segtools-length-distribution` generates two plots with different y axis labels referring to the same thing.

segment_sizes says "Segment label" whereas length_distribution only says "Label".

This PR changes the `R` code generating these figures such that the y axis labels are always "Label"
summary.html:
segtools-length-distribution generates two plots with different y axis labels referring to the same thing.

segment_sizes says "Segment label" whereas length_distribution only says "Label".

This PR changes the R code generating these figures such that the y axis labels are always "Label"
